## Common Misconceptions

| Myth | Reality |
|------|---------|
| Only for experts | Beginners are welcome everywhere |
| Need to know the whole codebase | You can start with one file |
| Requires huge time commitment | Even 30 minutes helps |
| Only code counts | Docs, tests, triage all matter |

## Finding the Right Project

Start with tools you already use.

- Check their GitHub for `good first issue` or `help wanted` labels
- Read the `CONTRIBUTING.md`
- Look at recent activity â€” is the project alive?
- Join their communication channel (Discord, Slack, mailing list)

## Staying Consistent

- Start small â€” don't aim for heroic PRs
- Set a rhythm (spend few mins every day)
  - Most days I just go over 10+ issues looking for gaps
- Celebrate small wins
- It's okay to take breaks

---

## Practical Tips

- Use `git log` and `git blame` to understand code history
- Run the test suite locally before submitting
- Write clear commit messages
- Reference the issue number in your PR
- Don't be afraid to ask questions
